CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

options.option_text: YES
NO

questions.question_text_1: Why is good design often hard to notice?
question_texts: Why is good design often hard to notice?

options.option_text: Because it is aesthetically pleasing
Because it functions flawlessly
Because it integrates seamlessly into user experience
Because it is visually striking

questions.question_text_1: In this example of the switchboard, what design challenge can be noted?
questions.question_text_2: In this example of the switchboard, what design challenge can be noted?
question_texts: In this example of the switchboard, what design challenge can be noted?
In this example of the switchboard, what design challenge can be noted?

options.option_text: The number of switches
The color of the switches
The mapping between switches and devices
The location of the switchboard

questions.question_text_1: What were the key principles of project management followed by the Konkan Railway team?
question_texts: What were the key principles of project management followed by the Konkan Railway team?

options.option_text: Limited communication and strict micromanagement.
Clear delegation of responsibilities, accountability of team members, andeffective communication grid.
Indirect delegation of responsibilities to lower levels.
Reliance on individual decision-making.

questions.question_text_1: How does a project differ from the routine operations of an organization?
question_texts: How does a project differ from the routine operations of an organization?

options.option_text: Projects have indefinite timelines.
Projects do not have unique deliverables.
Projects conclude once the goal is achieved, unlike routine operations.
Routine operations require specialized tools and techniques.

questions.question_text_1: What are the main phases of the project life cycle, as mentioned in the transcript?
question_texts: What are the main phases of the project life cycle, as mentioned in the transcript?

options.option_text: Planning, Executing, Monitoring, Closing
Initiating, Planning, Executing, Closing
Starting, Designing, Implementing, Closing
Initiating, Designing, Implementing, Closing

questions.question_text_1: What is the recommended methodology for project execution, and why is it suggested?
question_texts: What is the recommended methodology for project execution, and why is it suggested?

options.option_text: Waterfall methodology, because it provides a linear and sequential approachto project management.
Agile methodology combined with design thinking, as it allows for flexibilityand adaptation to changing circumstances.
Lean project management, because it focuses on minimizing waste andmaximizing value.
Scrum methodology, because it emphasizes incremental progress and regularfeedback.

questions.question_text_1: What information is included in a user persona?
question_texts: What information is included in a user persona?

options.option_text: Name, gender, age, location, occupation, other demographic details, etc.
Detailed information about the user's goals, high and low points during anaction, pain points, behaviors, and inferences.
Information about the user's fictional journey within the product.
Information about the user's favorite hobbies and interests.

questions.question_text_1: What is the purpose of dividing the customer journey map into "before," "during," and "after" phases?
question_texts: What is the purpose of dividing the customer journey map into "before," "during," and "after" phases?

options.option_text: To create a fictional storyline.
To ensure that the user follows a predefined script.
To track the emotional state of the user at different stages of product usage.
To provide a structured representation of the user's journey from preparationto completion.

questions.question_text_1: In customer journey mapping, why is it essential to focus on the emotional aspect of the user's experience?
question_texts: In customer journey mapping, why is it essential to focus on the emotional aspect of the user's experience?

options.option_text: To entertain the design team during brainstorming sessions.
To ensure that the persona has a compelling and engaging storyline.
To capture how the user feels at different stages of interacting with theproduct or service.
To generate creative content for marketing campaigns.

questions.question_text_1: During the time when GD Naidu started his bus company, what action did he take to understand the challenges faced by his drivers?
question_texts: During the time when GD Naidu started his bus company, what action did he take to understand the challenges faced by his drivers?

options.option_text: He conducted surveys among the drivers.
He personally became a driver for his own company for nearly a year.
He hired a consultant to assess the driver experience.
He observed the drivers from a distance without direct interaction.

questions.question_text_1: How can aesthetics impact the perception of a product?
question_texts: How can aesthetics impact the perception of a product?

options.option_text: It is the primary factor influencing the purchase decision.
It should not overshadow the importance of functionality and usability.
It directly correlates with the complexity of a product.
It is a secondary consideration for manufacturers.

questions.question_text_1: Why is simplicity a fundamental goal in technology design?
question_texts: Why is simplicity a fundamental goal in technology design?

options.option_text: To reduce manufacturing costs.
To make products more visually appealing.
To facilitate ease of use and enhance user experience.
To minimize the involvement of stakeholders in the design process.

questions.question_text_1: What are the three basic emotions the speaker suggests considering in storytelling?
question_texts: What are the three basic emotions the speaker suggests considering in storytelling?

options.option_text: Joyful, angry, peaceful
Happy, sad, neutral
Excited, frustrated, content
Energetic, relaxed, annoyed

questions.question_text_1: Why does the speaker emphasize the need to be open and flexible during the empathize exercise?
question_texts: Why does the speaker emphasize the need to be open and flexible during the empathize exercise?

options.option_text: To challenge the customer's viewpoint
To prevent emotional bias
To encourage different insights and perspectives
To maintain a strict focus on the task

questions.question_text_1: What is the next step after creating the customer journey map?
question_texts: What is the next step after creating the customer journey map?

options.option_text: Generating a list of problems
Conducting surveys and questionnaires
Developing a marketing strategy
Analyzing competitor data

questions.question_text_1: Why is it important to ensure the list of problems is consistent with the customer journey map?
question_texts: Why is it important to ensure the list of problems is consistent with the customer journey map?

options.option_text: To impress stakeholders with thorough documentation
To prevent forgetting key insights over time
To limit the number of identified problems
To focus exclusively on solvable issues

questions.question_text_1: What purpose do "How Might We" questions serve in the context of design thinking?
question_texts: What purpose do "How Might We" questions serve in the context of design thinking?

options.option_text: They function as declarative statements for problem-solving.
They help reframe problems as opportunities for creative solutions.
They provide definitive answers to complex challenges.
They offer concise problem summaries for analysis.

questions.question_text_1: How do "How Might We" questions transition between the stages of design thinking?
question_texts: How do "How Might We" questions transition between the stages of design thinking?

options.option_text: They are generated in Empathize and refined in Analyze.
They are primarily used in the Test stage to validate solutions.
They are not relevant to the Analyze stage.
They are introduced in Solve and revisited in Test.

questions.question_text_1: What is the significance of stopping the Multi-why analysis at a level where action can be taken?
question_texts: What is the significance of stopping the Multi-why analysis at a level where action can be taken?

options.option_text: It ensures that the problem is thoroughly analyzed.
It prevents overthinking and analysis paralysis.
It allows for deeper exploration of the problem.
It helps in generating more creative ideas.

questions.question_text_1: When employing the Conflict of Interest module, why is it important to delve into the underlying motivations of characters in movies? Example: Understanding the nuanced motives of Michael Corleone in "The Godfather" provides deeper insights into the conflicts he faces.
question_texts: When employing the Conflict of Interest module, why is it important to delve into the underlying motivations of characters in movies? Example: Understanding the nuanced motives of Michael Corleone in "The Godfather" provides deeper insights into the conflicts he faces.

options.option_text: To decipher intricate layers of conflicting desires and hidden agendas.
To simplify the conflict analysis process for learners.
To overlook character motivations in favor of plot-driven conflicts.
To streamline conflict resolution techniques.

questions.question_text_1: In the context of multi-why, why is it recommended to bring in analysts and experts for assistance?
question_texts: In the context of multi-why, why is it recommended to bring in analysts and experts for assistance?

options.option_text: To simplify the analysis process
To provide additional perspectives and insights
To speed up the decision-making
To reduce the need for in-depth analysis

questions.question_text_1: What is the main idea behind "Silent Brainstorming"?
question_texts: What is the main idea behind "Silent Brainstorming"?

options.option_text: Sharing ideas verbally to enhance creativity
Writing down ideas before voicing them out
Use silence as a potential idea in the user experience
Documenting brainstorming outcomes for future reference

questions.question_text_1: Why is considering potential user misuse, such as overloading, crucial in product design?
question_texts: Why is considering potential user misuse, such as overloading, crucial in product design?

options.option_text: To ensure the product aligns with industry safety standards
To avoid legal complications related to product usage
To prevent product failures caused by real-world usage
To minimize the need for regular maintenance

questions.question_text_1: Why is feedback crucial during product use?
question_texts: Why is feedback crucial during product use?

options.option_text: It provides information about the product's features.
It enhances the visual appeal of the product.
It is an integral part of the user experience.
It minimizes the need for regular maintenance.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are few major principles of Human-Centered Design?  [Select all that apply]:
question_texts: Which of the following are few major principles of Human-Centered Design?  [Select all that apply]:

options.option_text: Ensuring that we solve the core, root issues, not just the problem as presentedto us.
Focusing on technology and innovation.
Prioritizing aesthetics over functionality.
Continually testing and refining proposals to meet the intended audience'sneeds.

questions.question_text_1:
Read the case study, then answer the given subquestions.
 CASE INCIDENT
 InnoHealth Tech: Transforming Remote Healthcare
 InnoHealth Tech, a forward-thinking tech company, is on a mission to revolutionize remote healthcare. They've recently developed a cutting-edge wearable device capable of real-time vital sign monitoring. Jaya, their lead Design Thinking professional, is spearheading the project. Her goal is to fine-tune the device's user experience and make it a game-changer in the healthcare industry.  Jaya applied the 4 phase process of E.A.S.T Jaya's first step was conducting extensive research on healthcare professionals and patients.  During this she uncovered a complex challenge: while the device provided valuable data, it overwhelmed both patients and professionals alike. Jaya then collaborated with the tech team, brainstorming solutions that ranged from streamlined interfaces to advanced data analytics.  After rigorous prototyping, the team zeroed in on a mobile app. This app would present users with a simplified dashboard, offering personalized health recommendations based on the data. The challenge now was the app's promotion. They had a budget constraint but needed to make a significant impact in the healthcare market.

questions.question_text_1: Considering the complexities of remote healthcare, what strategic advantage does the wearable device provide in terms of real-time monitoring that traditional healthcare methods may struggle to achieve?
question_texts: Considering the complexities of remote healthcare, what strategic advantage does the wearable device provide in terms of real-time monitoring that traditional healthcare methods may struggle to achieve?

options.option_text: Enhanced patient-doctor communication
Timely intervention in critical situations
Reduction of overall healthcare costs
Integration with existing healthcare systems

questions.question_text_1: Considering the intricacies of user experience simplification, which potential challenge did Jaya need to contemplate while focusing on this aspect?
question_texts: Considering the intricacies of user experience simplification, which potential challenge did Jaya need to contemplate while focusing on this aspect?

options.option_text: Balancing data granularity with simplicity

question_texts: During the Solve Phase, what approach do you recommend Jaya and the tech team adopt to ensure that the proposed solutions align with the company's mission and technical capabilities?

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### Core Topics and Concepts

1. **Design Thinking Principles**
   - **Empathy**: Understanding user needs and experiences.
   - **User Persona**: Detailed profiles of target users including demographic details, goals, pain points, and behaviors.
   - **Customer Journey Mapping**: Structured representation of the user's journey divided into "before," "during," and "after" phases.
   - **Emotional Aspect**: Capturing how users feel at different stages of interaction.
   - **Silent Brainstorming**: Writing down ideas before voicing them to enhance creativity.

2. **Project Management**
   - **Project Life Cycle**: Initiating, Planning, Executing, Closing.
   - **Project vs. Routine Operations**: Projects have definite timelines and unique deliverables.
   - **Methodologies**: Agile methodology combined with design thinking for flexibility and adaptation.

3. **Human-Centered Design**
   - **Core Principles**: Solving root issues, continual testing, and refining proposals.
   - **User Experience**: Ensuring simplicity, functionality, and usability.
   - **Feedback**: Integral part of the user experience to refine and improve products.

4. **Problem-Solving Techniques**
   - **"How Might We" Questions**: Reframe problems as opportunities for creative solutions.
   - **Multi-Why Analysis**: Stopping at a level where action can be taken to prevent overthinking.
   - **Conflict of Interest Module**: Understanding underlying motivations and conflicts.

5. **Product Design**
   - **Aesthetics and Functionality**: Aesthetics should not overshadow functionality and usability.
   - **User Misuse**: Considering potential misuse to prevent product failures.
   - **Prototyping and Testing**: Rigorous prototyping and testing to ensure product effectiveness.

6. **Case Study: InnoHealth Tech**
   - **Real-Time Monitoring**: Strategic advantage in timely intervention in critical situations.
   - **User Experience Simplification**: Balancing data granularity with simplicity.
   - **User-Centric Approach**: Ensuring solutions align with the company's mission and technical capabilities.
   - **Budget Constraints**: Effective strategies for promotion and long-term relevance.

#### Important Principles

- **Empathy and User-Centric Design**: Fundamental to understanding and solving user problems.
- **Iterative Process**: Continuous testing, feedback, and refinement.
- **Collaboration and Communication**: Clear delegation of responsibilities and effective communication.
- **Flexibility and Openness**: Encouraging different insights and perspectives during the design process.

#### Mermaid Knowledge Graph

```mermaid
graph TD;
    A[Design Thinking] --> B[Empathy]
    A --> C[User Persona]
    A --> D[Customer Journey Mapping]
    A --> E[Silent Brainstorming]
    B --> F[Understanding User Needs]
    C --> G[Demographic Details]
    C --> H[Goals and Pain Points]
    D --> I[Before Phase]
    D --> J[During Phase]
    D --> K[After Phase]
    E --> L[Enhancing Creativity]

    M[Project Management] --> N[Project Life Cycle]
    M --> O[Project vs. Routine Operations]
    M --> P[Methodologies]
    N --> Q[Initiating]
    N --> R[Planning]
    N --> S[Executing]
    N --> T[Closing]
    O --> U[Definite Timelines]
    O --> V[Unique Deliverables]
    P --> W[Agile Methodology]
    P --> X[Design Thinking]

    Y[Human-Centered Design] --> Z[Core Principles]
    Y --> AA[User Experience]
    Y --> AB[Feedback]
    Z --> AC[Solving Root Issues]
    Z --> AD[Continual Testing]
    AA --> AE[Simplicity]
    AA --> AF[Functionality]
    AB --> AG[Refinement]

    AH[Problem-Solving Techniques] --> AI["How Might We Questions"]
    AH --> AJ[Multi-Why Analysis]
    AH --> AK[Conflict of Interest Module]
    AI --> AL[Creative Solutions]
    AJ --> AM[Actionable Level]
    AK --> AN[Underlying Motivations]

    AO[Product Design] --> AP[Aesthetics and Functionality]
    AO --> AQ[User Misuse]
    AO --> AR[Prototyping and Testing]
    AP --> AS[Functionality Over Aesthetics]
    AQ --> AT[Preventing Product Failures]
    AR --> AU[Effectiveness]

    AV[InnoHealth Tech Case Study] --> AW[Real-Time Monitoring]
    AV --> AX[User Experience Simplification]
    AV --> AY[User-Centric Approach]
    AV --> AZ[Budget Constraints]
    AW --> BA[Timely Intervention]
    AX --> BB[Data Granularity]
    AY --> BC[Mission Alignment]
    AZ --> BD[Organic Marketing]
```

This summary and knowledge graph should help you focus on the essential topics and concepts for your exam preparation.
